author: By Emma Bubola
title: Russian influencers are cutting up their Chanel bags in protest of the company’s wartime policies.
description: The iconic French brand is asking customers to attest that they will not use their newly purchased items in Russia, sparking a social media protest.
content: When Marina Ermoshkina, a Russian TV presenter, learned that employees at a Chanel store in Dubai had refused to sell a high-end bag to a Russian customer, after asking her to sign papers attesting that she would not wear the bag in Russia, she reacted in shock.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Denver Captures Its Ninth N.C.A.A. Hockey Championship
description: The Pioneers are now tied for most Division I men’s college hockey titles with Michigan, the team they beat in overtime in the national semifinal round.
content: BOSTON — Ryan Barrow arrived at the University of Denver in the fall of 2017 from Banff, Alberta, months after its ice hockey team had won the N.C.A.A. Division I men’s championship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: S&P Global Places Russia in ‘Selective Default’
description: Russia was unable to use dollars held in American banks to make a payment of about $650 million on its debt. It used rubles instead.
content: S&P Global has placed Russia under a “selective default” rating after the Russian government said last week that it had repaid about $650 million in dollar-denominated debt in rubles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Israel’s Ukraine Policy Prompts Scrutiny of Russian-Israeli Oligarchs
description: Israel has expressed solidarity with Ukraine but avoided direct criticism of Russia, raising questions about Russian-Israeli businessmen close to the Kremlin.
content: JERUSALEM — When Avigdor Liberman, Israel’s Soviet-born finance minister, condemned the apparent atrocities in Bucha, Ukraine, this past week, he was careful not to blame Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Monika Pronczuk
title: Ukraine’s Draft Dodgers Face Guilt, Shame and Reproach
description: Thousands of Ukrainian men are avoiding military service, putting them on risky paths into Europe. Among Ukrainians, it’s stirring a complicated debate.
content: CHISINAU, Moldova – Vova Klever, a young, successful fashion photographer from Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv, did not see himself in this war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Salman Masood
title: Pakistan Closes a Chaotic Political Chapter. It May Not Be the Climax.
description: After Imran Khan’s ouster as prime minister, the legacy of his time in office is a continued military dominance of public affairs and deep polarization that could turn violent.
content: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — In the last hours before the midnight deadline for a no-confidence motion in Pakistan’s Parliament, the capital was on the brink.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘My Husband and I Got Married at the City Clerk’s Office in February’
description: A celebratory brunch, testing a theory on the M14 and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Putin, Rooting Out War Critics, Turns Russians Against Russians
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, April 10, 2022.
content: “Repressions are not just done by the hands of the state authorities. They are also done by the hands of regular citizens.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully and Shlomo Schorr
title: Why This Coastal County Has the Highest Covid Death Rate in Its State
description: Ocean County, a predominantly white and middle-class community in central New Jersey, also has low vaccination rates.
content: Ocean County, a coastal region in central New Jersey, is home to some of the state’s most exclusive waterfront communities and its fastest-growing town, Lakewood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Wind Energy Company to Pay $8 Million in Killings of 150 Eagles
description: ESI Energy pleaded guilty based on the documented “blunt force trauma” deaths of golden eagles struck by fast-moving turbine blades, prosecutors said.
content: A wind energy company pleaded guilty last week to killing at least 150 eagles at its wind farms and was ordered to pay $8 million in fines and restitution, federal prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: $4 a Gallon
description: More expensive gas could have lasting consequences.
content: If you were hoping for much cheaper gas anytime soon, I have some bad news: Prices probably won’t drop much for at least a few months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Eric Adams, N.Y.C.’s mayor, tests positive for the coronavirus.
description: Mr. Adams has been focused on reopening the city after cases rose during the Omicron surge over the winter.
content: Eric Adams, the mayor of New York City, tested positive for the coronavirus on Sunday, his 100th day in office, the mayor’s office announced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: An uptick in U.S. virus cases is concerning but not surprising, Fauci says.
description: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci said on Sunday that the virus was still a threat, but that people needed to decide for themselves what risks to take.
content: The uptick in new U.S. coronavirus cases in recent days is concerning, Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the nation’s top infectious disease expert, said Sunday. But he suggested that the rise was not yet cause for alarm and that officials were monitoring it “very, very carefully.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Scottie Scheffler Wins His First Masters Championship
description: The 25-year-old American, a rising star on the PGA Tour and world No. 1, held off Rory McIlroy and Cameron Smith to win by three strokes.
content: AUGUSTA, Ga. — It would have been understandable if Scottie Scheffler, who has been the paragon of poise as he charged to the No. 1 ranking in men’s golf this year, felt just a bit unnerved during the first hour of Sunday’s final round of the Masters Tournament. The three-stroke lead he held over his closest pursuer, Cameron Smith, when the day began had shrunk to a single stroke in the opening two holes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: A College Fights ‘Leftist Academics’ by Expanding Into Charter Schools
description: Hillsdale College is building a national charter school network. Tennessee invited the college to start 50 of them, using public funds.
content: With only 1,500 students on a small-town campus in southern Michigan, Hillsdale College is far from the power corridors of government and top-ranked universities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Jordan Mooney, an Avatar of Punk Style, Dies at 66
description: Swathed in rubber and glowering from spiked heels, she was a fearsome figurehead for a generation of disaffected English teenagers.
content: Jordan Mooney, better known as simply Jordan, a glowering, beehived Valkyrie in rubber and spiked heels who became an avatar of punk style when she presided over the transgressive London boutique that hatched the Sex Pistols and other provocations, died on April 3 in Seaford, East Sussex. She was 66.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Never Gonna Give You Up
description: Rachel Simon makes her New York Times Crossword debut.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to Rachel Simon, who is making her constructing debut in the New York Times Crossword today. When I saw her byline, I immediately went to check how many other Rachels had published crosswords in The Times, and I am pleased to welcome Ms. Simon to the elite club that, until today, included just me and Rachel Maddow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Playoff Makeovers May Upend the N.B.A. Championship Chase
description: Injured stars could return for the postseason, creating an undercurrent of unpredictability for their opponents.
content: Stephen Curry appeared at a recent practice for the Golden State Warriors without a walking boot on his sprained left foot. In Los Angeles, the Clippers’ Kawhi Leonard, who has not played all season, was spotted by local reporters participating in shooting drills. And the Denver Nuggets’ Jamal Murray, also sidelined since last season, is again soaring for dunks, according to some impeccable sources: his own teammates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: ‘Cabaret,’ Starring Eddie Redmayne, Sweeps Olivier Awards
description: The musical won seven awards at Britain’s equivalent of the Tonys. A puppet-filled adaptation of “Life of Pi” and a “Back to the Future” musical also won big.
content: LONDON — A revival of “Cabaret” that has been the talk of London’s theater world since opening in December, on Sunday swept the Olivier Awards, Britain’s equivalent of the Tonys.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Dylan McDermott Wants to Be a Good Guy for a Change
description: After spending the past several years playing pimps and crime bosses, the actor is trying on heroism in “FBI: Most Wanted.”
content: Dylan McDermott was familiar with the darkness required to play Richard Wheatley, the sinister businessman and furtive crime boss in “Law & Order: Organized Crime.” He’d had people like that in his life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai and Isabella Moore
title: An Australia Homecoming, Mixed With Yearning and Trepidation
description: When “Fortress Australia” sealed its borders, thousands of citizens were stuck abroad. When allowed to return home, a reporter wondered how she would find the country — and how it would find her.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — The tangy smell of eucalyptus leaves lining the streets. A casual friendliness even from strangers. Ten types of Asian cuisine in a 100-yard radius of the city center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks
title: A Stricken Ukrainian City Empties, and Those Left Fear What’s Next
description: After the deadly strike on the train station in Kramatorsk, Ukraine, those who stayed behind are grim about the future: “We think we will be swept off the face of the earth.”
content: KRAMATORSK, Ukraine — Two days after more than 50 people were killed on its platforms by a missile strike, the only sounds at the Kramatorsk railway station on Sunday morning were a distant air-raid siren and the rhythmic sweeping of broken glass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: On the Border, Buying Clothes by the Pound at Ropa Usada Shops
description: Like thrift shops on steroids, giant used-clothing stores are part of the culture and economic life along the border with Mexico.
content: McALLEN, Texas — A mountain of clothes swallowed half of Juani Lira’s petite body, from the waist down. But the 67-year-old did not seem to mind. Ms. Lira closely inspected a pair of black shorts studded with rhinestones and tossed them behind her, unimpressed. Too flashy for her teenage granddaughter, she murmured.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Stout
title: Jack Higgins, Author of ‘The Eagle Has Landed,’ Dies at 92
description: Under various pseudonyms, he wrote adventure novels that sold more than 250 million copies worldwide.
content: Jack Higgins, the author of dozens of best-selling adventure novels, most notably “The Eagle Has Landed,” a hugely popular tale about a band of German commandos who infiltrate Britain to try to kidnap Prime Minister Winston Churchill during World War II, died on Saturday at his home on the English Channel island of Jersey. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: A Popular British Politician Falls From Grace Over a Tax Scandal
description: Rishi Sunak was once considered a potential successor to Prime Minister Boris Johnson. Now he faces scrutiny over his wealthy wife’s tax status, and over holding an American green card while in office.
content: LONDON — Just two months ago, Rishi Sunak, a popular, fast-rising British politician who serves as chancellor of the Exchequer, looked like a good bet to replace the country’s scandal-scarred prime minister, Boris Johnson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson Gets Advice from ‘S.N.L.’
description: Ego Nwodim played the newly confirmed Supreme Court justice for “Saturday Night Live,” in an episode hosted by Jake Gyllenhaal.
content: History was made earlier this week when Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson was confirmed by the Senate on Thursday, making her the first Black woman to become a Justice of the Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: City Ties Liverpool, Well Aware That One Point May Be Plenty
description: In a Premier League season of the finest margins, four goals add to the drama but don’t change the title math for Pep Guardiola and Manchester City.
content: MANCHESTER, England — Midway through the second half, as the game on which a season hung started to build in a nerve-shredding, pulse-straining crescendo, Liverpool’s Trent Alexander-Arnold found himself waiting to take a throw-in within a couple of feet of Pep Guardiola, the Manchester City manager.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia Heyward and Sophie Kasakove
title: Texas Will Dismiss Murder Charge Against Woman Connected to ‘Self-Induced Abortion’
description: A district attorney said on Sunday that the woman “cannot and should not” be prosecuted.
content: The murder charge against a woman in Texas in connection with a “self-induced abortion” will be dismissed, a Texas district attorney announced Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Creswell
title: The Home Cooks (and Start-Ups) Betting on Prepared Meals
description: Tens of billions of dollars are being spent on what, where and how consumers will eat in the coming years. Laws and regulations aren’t always keeping up.
content: Several days a week, Jullet Achan moves around the kitchen of her apartment in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, stirring up dishes from her Surinamese background: fragrant batches of goat curry, root vegetable soup and her own take on chicken chow mein.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: Review: The Choreographer Kyle Marshall’s Spacious Slow Burns
description: Marshall’s solo “I & I,” set to reggae, was the highlight of his company’s program at the Chelsea Factory.
content: Even before the pandemic forced people into solitude, the choreographer Kyle Marshall had been working on a solo. In February 2020 he shared a work-in-progress at Danspace Project, in which he was asking questions about his Jamaican heritage, his queerness and the relationship between them. I still recall the quiet, steady force of his running in loops around the St. Mark’s Church sanctuary, alongside the pulse of Bob Marley’s “Exodus.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Kate Kelly
title: Before Giving Billions to Jared Kushner, Saudi Investment Fund Had Big Doubts
description: Before committing $2 billion to Mr. Kushner’s fledgling firm, officials at a fund led by the Saudi crown prince questioned taking such a big risk.
content: Six months after leaving the White House, Jared Kushner secured a $2 billion investment from a fund led by the Saudi crown prince, a close ally during the Trump administration, despite objections from the fund’s advisers about the merits of the deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kulish and Rebecca R. Ruiz
title: The Fortunes of MacKenzie Scott
description: Three decades after worrying about making rent, she is now giving away billions — all while trying to keep herself out of the spotlight.
content: The billionaire philanthropist MacKenzie Scott once recounted, in a television interview, a Chinese folk tale sometimes known as “The Lost Horse.” The story is about the reversals of fortune a farmer experiences after his prized stallion runs away. It can also be read as a summary of her philosophy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Macron to Face Le Pen for President as French Gravitate Toward Extremes
description: President Emmanuel Macron and the hard-right leader Marine Le Pen will compete for a second time in a runoff on April 24.
content: PARIS — President Emmanuel Macron will face Marine Le Pen, the French far-right leader, in the runoff of France’s presidential elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | April 11, 2022
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Forget Heartbreak Hill. It’s Boston’s Downhills That Cause the Real Pain.
description: The uphill sections generally get all the attention on the Boston Marathon course. But the route is what is known as a “net downhill” race.
content: The Boston Marathon is a little more than a week away, and that means lots of runners are fretting over those final climbs, especially the notorious Heartbreak Hill at mile 20.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: How a Cancer Diagnosis Makes Jesus’ Death and Resurrection Mean More
description: “I look at Easter and I say, ‘Because of this, I can face anything.’”
content: I’ve talked to Timothy Keller several times since he was diagnosed with Stage 4 pancreatic cancer almost two years ago. What strikes me each time is that it’s easy to forget he has a fatal disease. He is calm, sage-like, cheerful and still deeply curious about others and the world around him. He always asks me, genuinely, how I am doing and listens intently as I tell him. He offers advice, wisdom, and even sympathy, though my complaints are all comparatively small compared to facing cancer. It’s hard to have a conversation with him without feeling more hopeful and buoyant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: New Era Begins at Warner Bros., Tinged With Nostalgia
description: With a new owner, the 99-year-old movie studio appears headed back to its traditional sweet spot as an entertainment company. But the business of Hollywood is no longer the same.
content: LOS ANGELES — By 2018, almost every golden-age Hollywood studio had been conquered by outside forces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: Dance Theater of Harlem’s Soulful Ballet to Stevie Wonder
description: Robert Garland’s “Higher Ground” combines classical ballet and vernacular Black dance to sharpen the social commentary in Wonder songs from the ’70s.
content: Dance is perfectly capable of saying something all by itself, but music can help. Sung lyrics are more perilous, introducing the threat of literalism, yet the combination of dance and words, handled right, can heighten meaning. One example: Robert Garland’s intensely affecting “Higher Ground,” which had its New York premiere this week when Dance Theater of Harlem returned to New York City Center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: At the Masters, Tiger Woods Finishes, a Victory in Itself
description: By Sunday, the crowds that swarmed his opening rounds of the tournament had thinned somewhat. Woods finished 13 over, but the score seemed beside the point.
content: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Tiger Woods had 212 yards to the fifth green on Sunday morning. Holding a long iron, he swung with appropriate velocity and rhythm. But something was amiss at contact with the ball, and in the millisecond it took for Woods to transition from downswing to follow-through, he let go of the club. It flung to the ground over his left shoulder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cora Engelbrecht
title: A fleet of volunteer bus drivers is helping people escape eastern Ukraine.
description: After a Russian strike killed more than 50 people at a train station, Ukrainians are accelerating efforts to evacuate by road.
content: Two days after a Russian missile strike hit a train station in eastern Ukraine’s city of Kramatorsk, killing more than 50 people, volunteer drivers across the Donetsk region are coming forward to help residents still looking to flee before an anticipated onslaught from Russian forces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J.S. Marcus
title: One Opera, Three Acts, Three Different Stagings
description: In Stuttgart, Wagner’s “Die Walküre” is being divided among a trio of creative teams with divergent visions.
content: STUTTGART, Germany — In the late 1990s, the Stuttgart State Opera in Germany raised some eyebrows and hackles when it divided the four operas in Richard Wagner’s epic “Der Ring des Nibelungen” among four directors, one installment each.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons, Jeffery C. Mays and Dana Rubinstein
title: Mayor Adams’s First 100 Days: A Focus on Crime, Covid and Crises
description: Eric Adams has served as a cheerleader for New York City’s revival while taking an aggressive stance against homeless encampments and signs of lawlessness.
content: On an unusually cold morning in late March, Mayor Eric Adams began his day visiting a child-care center in Queens. Roughly seven miles away, police officers in Brooklyn were carrying out his order to clear homeless encampments, tossing away tents and other belongings in a garbage truck as part of a new public safety initiative.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton and David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Crypto Industry Helps Write, and Pass, Its Own Agenda in State Capitols
description: In the absence of federal regulations, crypto lobbyists and executives are going state by state to get favorable rules enacted. Many lawmakers have been willing partners.
content: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — The debate took less than four minutes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman and Roger Cohen
title: Macron’s pursuit of a high-tech economy stirs pre-election resentment.
description: A start-up boom in France was a core objective for Emmanuel Macron, a young leader elected president five years ago as a restless disrupter, promising to pry open the economy and make it competitive in the 21st century.
content: A start-up boom in France was a core objective for Emmanuel Macron, a young leader elected president five years ago as a restless disrupter, promising to pry open the economy and make it competitive in the 21st century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Gallagher
title: My Advice for American Veterans Who Want to Get on a Plane to Ukraine
description: People there are suffering. Discouraging my fellow veterans from going there would be both hypocritical and disingenuous.
content: Like many people around the world, I viewed the images that have emerged in the last few days from Bucha, Ukraine, with horror and fury. I know that all wars cause ruin and destruction, that all wars destroy and shatter innocent lives. But although I understand this intellectually, and although I saw my fair share of human suffering as a soldier in Iraq, the seemingly endless mass graves and the bound and desecrated corpses left behind in Bucha by the fleeing Russian military felt to me some new circle of hell.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Few Cars, Lots of Customers: Why Autos Are an Inflation Risk
description: Economists are betting that supply chains for all kinds of goods will heal, shortages will ease and price gains will slow. Cars are a wild card in those forecasts.
content: Corina Diehl is eager for more sedans and pickup trucks to sell her customers in and around the Pittsburgh area, but as the pandemic enters its third year, cars remain in short supply and the squeeze on inventory shows no sign of abating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Doug Mills and Alan Blinder
title: The Roar of the Crowd Returns
description: It has been two years since the Masters Tournament welcomed a full house of spectators who live and die with every shot.
content: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The roars were absent or diminished for two Masters Tournaments, so many spectators kept away because of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Trump Endorses Dr. Oz in Pennsylvania Senate Race
description: The former president threw his weight behind the celebrity doctor, who is running for the Republican nomination for senator in a key state.
content: Wading into a tight Republican Senate primary in Pennsylvania, former President Donald J. Trump endorsed Mehmet Oz on Saturday, throwing his weight behind the former star of “The Dr. Oz Show,” who has been attacked by rivals as a closet liberal. Dr. Oz’s celebrity appears to have been a deciding factor for the former president, whose own political career was grounded in reality television.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Mets Can’t Win ’Em All, but Signs Point to Winning a Lot
description: The team lost for the first time in four games this season amid encouraging signs that it could contend for its first postseason spot since 2016.
content: WASHINGTON — It is hard to draw any conclusions after four games. That is merely 2.5 percent of the 162-game regular season, so please read the next sentence with that in mind. The Mets are one of the best teams in Major League Baseball.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Bistline, Inês Azevedo, Chris Bataille and Steven Davis
title: We Are Wasting Time on These Climate Debates. The Next Steps are Clear.
description: We don’t know exactly what a net-zero emissions energy system will look like, but we know enough to keep us busy for at least a decade.
content: The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change report, which was released last week and which we co-authored with many colleagues, offers hope for limiting global warming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: How Do We Deal With a Superpower Led by a War Criminal?
description: There’s never been a pariah state as consequential as Russia.
content: It is hard to believe, but now impossible to deny, that the broad framework that kept much of the world stable and prospering since the end of the Cold War has been seriously fractured by Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine. In ways we hadn’t fully appreciated, a lot of that framework rested on the West’s ability to coexist with Putin as he played “bad boy,” testing the limits of the world order but never breaching them at scale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Fisher
title: Why Calls for War Crimes Justice Over Ukraine Face Long Odds
description: If those in power act as if they are immune to the laws of war, it may be because they often are. But following through is not necessarily an empty exercise.
content: This past week, as Ukrainian forces retook the town of Bucha to find its streets littered with the bodies of bound and shot civilians, and as rockets rained on a train station packed with fleeing families, killing dozens, two words were on the lips of diplomats, world leaders and rights groups: war crimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah A. Topol, Jack D'Isidoro, Aaron Esposito, John Woo, Elisheba Ittoop and David Mason
title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Battle for the Mural — and the Future of Belarus’
description: How an act of graffiti at a playground in Minsk turned into a campaign of defiance against an increasingly totalitarian regime.
content: For more than two decades, Belarus existed in an equilibrium of quiet authoritarianism. If the government’s repressions didn’t directly touch them, most Belarusians tolerated them. But over the course of 2020, the country’s history and identity, which never much interested a majority of people who lived there, became something they would sacrifice their lives for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Solis
title: The Week in Business: Elon Musk’s Newest Venture
description: Europe agreed to ban Russian coal. A former Goldman Sachs banker was convicted for his role in a $4 billion fraud. And the latest reading on inflation comes out this week.
content: Twitter announced last week that Elon Musk would join its board after he bought a 9.2 percent stake in the company, making him its largest shareholder. Mr. Musk had reached out to Twitter’s chief executive, Parag Agrawal, before buying the company shares to tell Mr. Agrawal that he wanted to discuss improvements to Twitter, people with knowledge of the discussions said. Mr. Musk’s board seat expires in 2024, and he has agreed not to buy more than 14.9 percent of Twitter’s stock. But unlike some other members of Twitter’s board, he did not sign an agreement barring him from influencing the company’s policies. Mr. Musk, who has gotten into trouble for his own tweets, has publicly criticized Twitter for its content moderation policies and advocated open-source algorithms on the platform. He asked his more than 80 million followers last month if they wanted the capacity to edit tweets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Kasakove
title: Woman in Texas Charged With Murder in Connection With ‘Self-Induced Abortion’
description: Whether the woman had the abortion or was aiding one was unclear.
content: A South Texas sheriff’s official said on Saturday that a 26-year-old woman had been indicted on a murder charge in connection with the “death of an individual through a self-induced abortion.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Monday Briefing: Russian Troops Mass in East Ukraine
description: Plus Macron and Le Pen move to the runoff for the French presidency.
content: Russian troops are expected to carry out a major offensive from the city of Izium to Dnipro, a strategic target in the Donbas region of eastern Ukraine, according to U.S. military officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: Molly Shannon’s Memoir Is Filled With Mischief and Pathos
description: “Hello, Molly!,” the former “Saturday Night Live” star’s new book, recounts early family tragedy and a career of transgressive humor.
content: Some people break into show business; others burst. Like her famous character on “Saturday Night Live,” the nervous Catholic schoolgirl Mary Katherine Gallagher, Molly Shannon was more of a battering ram, laying siege to the false-fronted structures of Hollywood with blunt, repetitive force. When you reach the part in her new memoir, “Hello, Molly!,” where the fortresses finally crumble for her, you want to get out the pom-poms and cheer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Suhasini Raj and Saumya Khandelwal
title: Facing Disastrous Floods, They Turned to Mangrove Trees for Protection
description: In the Sundarbans, an ecological treasure straddling India and Bangladesh that is now on the front lines of climate change, local women are leading an effort to mitigate the dangers of rising waters.
content: LAKSHMIPUR, India — The women adjusted their binoculars around their necks, secured their bright green saris and climbed onto a motorboat to begin their weekly patrol in the Sundarbans, one of the largest deltas in the world and an urgent case study on the effects of climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: In a Village Divided, Palestinians See Their Hold on Territory Eroding
description: Carved up over decades, the village of Walaja sits partly in the occupied West Bank and partly in Jerusalem. Palestinians say this type of fragmentation undermines prospects for a state.
content: WALAJA, West Bank — On a gray metal gate that Israel built in the Palestinian village of Walaja hangs a biting sign: “Living behind this damned door and this spiteful wall is your brother and your son Omar Essa Hajajlah.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola, Valeriya Safronova and Maria Varenikova
title: ‘Everything Was Destroyed’: War Hits Ukraine’s Farms
description: The Russian invasion is pummeling Ukraine’s agriculture, threatening harvests in Europe’s breadbasket and contributing to a global food crisis.
content: The farmer was working in his field on a recent morning when a neighbor called to tell him that his warehouses had been shelled. He rushed back and found them on fire and one of his workers lying on the ground with shrapnel lodged in his head.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt and Luke Broadwater
title: Jan. 6 Panel Has Evidence for Criminal Referral of Trump, but Splits on Sending
description: Despite concluding that it has enough evidence, the committee is concerned that making a referral to the Justice Department would backfire by politicizing the investigation into the Capitol riot.
content: WASHINGTON — The leaders of the House committee investigating the Capitol attack have grown divided over whether to make a criminal referral to the Justice Department of former President Donald J. Trump, even though they have concluded that they have enough evidence to do so, people involved in the discussions said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia Heyward
title: Maryland Lawmakers Expand Abortion Access, Overriding Governor’s Veto
description: The new law allows trained medical professionals other than physicians to perform abortions and requires insurance providers to cover more costs.
content: Maryland is joining 14 other states in allowing trained medical professionals other than physicians to perform abortions. That change is part of a bill expanding abortion rights that was passed Saturday by state lawmakers, overriding the veto of Gov. Larry Hogan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: The Boston Marathon’s Brainless Bigotry
description: The race’s organizers pull an Otter.
content: Historical parallels often spring to mind when it comes to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Broadway Bets Big on a Spring Rebound. Will the Virus Cooperate?
description: It will be the busiest April for Broadway openings in more than a decade. But some of its biggest stars have been sidelined by positive tests.
content: After a gloomy winter in which the Omicron variant shriveled Broadway’s lucrative holiday season, New York’s vaunted theater industry has been betting on a big spring, nearly doubling the number of shows on offer as the pandemic-battered business thirsts for a rebound.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Otis
title: His Alter Ego: Comic Book Correspondent
description: George Gene Gustines, an operations manager at The Times, carved out a reporting beat for himself by owning up to his passion.
content: George Gene Gustines, whose alliterative byline evokes many a superhero alter ego, has, fittingly, been the unofficial New York Times comic book correspondent for nearly 20 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Misty Copeland
title: Misty Copeland on ‘Serenade,’ Democracy and the Art of Movement
description: The ballet dancer reviews Toni Bentley’s sixth book: part memoir, part ode to George Balanchine and the art form he immortalized.
content: SERENADE A Balanchine Story By Toni Bentley
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Johnny Depp and Amber Heard to Face Off in Defamation Trial
description: Mr. Depp sued his ex-wife, Ms. Heard, for an op-ed she wrote in The Washington Post referring to herself as a “public figure representing domestic abuse.”
content: The actor Johnny Depp could not convince a judge in London that he was innocent of allegations that he had abused his former wife, the actress Amber Heard, but in a trial starting Monday, the actor will take his defamation complaint to a jury in Virginia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: A Reporter Returns to Australia, a Pandemic Later
description: Earlier this year, I boarded a plane home for the first time since the pandemic began.
content: Earlier this year, I boarded a plane home for the first time since the pandemic began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Foley, Yousur Al-Hlou, Masha Froliak, Axel Boada and Nailah Morgan
title: ‘We’ll Bury Them, Like Humans’: Ukrainian Officials Identify Bodies in Bucha
description: Following the withdrawal of Russian forces from a Kyiv suburb, officials examined and documented the bodies of those who lost their lives in the war.
content: Following the withdrawal of Russian forces from a Kyiv suburb, officials examined and documented the bodies of those who lost their lives in the war.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 10, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, April 10, 2022.
content: An article on Page 7 this weekend about the director Lileana Blain-Cruz’s Broadway directing debut with “The Skin of Our Teeth,” in one instance, misstates her given name. It is Lileana, not Lily; she does not use the nickname Lily.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Try a deluxe open-faced turkey sandwich, salmon soba noodles with ponzu and more recipes for the days ahead.
content: Good morning. For a long time, my go-to diner order was an open-faced hot turkey sandwich with extra gravy and cranberry sauce, sometimes with mashed potatoes, often with fries. It was, to me, a pinnacle of luxury on the cheap: a savory layer cake of turkey and white bread beneath a glossy fondant of gravy.
source.name: The New York Times
